social_posts.post_text:
Welcome to the Nike LA Hoops Hotline! 📞🏀

Need basketball advice? We have a team of basketball legends and experts who are ready to help you take your game to the next level!

Drop a question in the comments, follow @nikela and let’s get better today!

#nike #nikela #nikebasketball #nikehoops #justdoit #lebron #lakers #lasparks #usctrojans

When was the last time you played dodgeball?

Dodgeball is one of our go-to warm ups to start practice. Your warm ups don’t have to be boring and monotonous. They can be fun, engaging and competitive. 

Dribble Dodgeball is better than stationary drills-even for beginners. In one warm up game you’re improving your perception, reaction, quickness, shiftiness and ball control. All skills you need to be a confident ball handler in games.

Save this drill and have a little fun in your next workout.

If you can dodge a ball, you can dodge a defender.

Get better today!

#truepointguard #dodgeball #basketballdrills #ballhandling #ballhandlingdrills #warmup #handles #basketballtraining

‘Tis the season to get better! 🏀🎁

Come out this Saturday for a FREE Nike clinic at Mira Costa High School to improve your decision making, enjoy a yoga flow and much more! 

The registration link is in my bio. Reserve your spot today because this clinic is filling up fast!

#nike #nikela #nikebasketball #basketballtraining #holidayhoops #basketballcoach #ballislife #basketballtrainer

What’s your dream?

Is it to make a team? To play varsity? Earn a scholarship? Go pro?

Whatever your dream is know these two things:

1. Thousands of other people have the same dream and are competing for the same opportunities

2. Your hustle has to match your dream.

Find ways to separate yourself. Seek out opportunities to learn from other coaches and players who’ve been where you’re trying to go.

Do more than what’s required. Get up extra shots. Play against better players. Train more on your own. Study the game. Like Kobe said: learn, absorb and be a sponge.

Tomorrow I’m hosting a free Nike clinic for the hustlers. Come get better and get a step closer to realizing your dreams.

Link in bio!

#nikela #nikebasketball #basketballtrainer #kobebryant #holidayhoops #basketballplayer #ballislife #chaseyourdreams

Improving decision making is a big part of our training. I believe it’s the most important skill we need in the game yet it’s the most undertrained.

In order to be playmakers and effective scorers, athletes must be able to perceive where their defender is and quickly make a decision (perception & action). The is simply the nature of the game so the majority of your training should reflect that.

So while closing our eyes to start the drill is a little different and unorthodox, it’s a fun small-sided game that will help you improve your decision making so that you create easier scoring opportunities in games. 

Save this drill and get better today.

#basketballskills #basketballdrills #basketballtrainer #basketballtraining #smallsidedgames #hooplife #pointguard #basketballmoves #hoopdreams

Basketball is more than just a sport.

Basketball is community
Basketball is opportunity
Basketball is refuge
Basketball is growth

Basketball is a game that has the power to change lives. I don’t want to be remembered for how many championships I won or for how many points I averaged in my career. I want to be remembered for using this game to offer hope.

Impact trumps championships.

I’m supremely grateful for the opportunities to partner with @nikela to make an impact in our community through basketball.

You never know where this game will take you.

Keep developing your craft
Keep using your gift
Keep doing things that matter

What do you want to be remembered for?

Hoopers, Coaches, Trainers, Parents, and Fans…Let’s close the year out and share some of our wins!

What was your favorite basketball memory of 2022? 

Let me know in the comments 👇🏾

#smallwins #nikebasketball #basketballtrainer #ballislife #basketballreels #basketball2022 #girlsbasketball #happynewyear #nba

As I reflect on 2022, my heart is simply filled with so much gratitude.

I’m grateful for my TPGFAM and every player/parent who has trusted me with their development. 

I’m grateful for my business partner @tpgcoachrobbie who continues to change the lives of our athletes through character development and mental training.

I’m grateful for @no_i.d. His mentorship as it relates to pedagogy and skill acquisition has made me a better trainer.

I’m grateful for the opportunity I had to share my story on the @coachjrperformance podcast.

I’m grateful for the @nikela team for believing in me and partnering with me to host clinics for our community.

And lastly, I’m grateful for all of the love and support you all have shown me throughout this journey. Thanks for rocking with me. I love this community!

Let’s continue to grow and do thing that matter in 2023! ✨

Do you want to improve your shooting this year? Do you lack confidence in your shot? Are frustrated and just want to hit more shots in games? Read on:

1. As you probably already know the first important thing is to ensure you have proper form. While everyone won’t shoot the same way, there are certain mechanics that every great shooter adheres to. You should have a solid foundation, the ball should move before your body and your shooting hand should be under the ball before the release. There are other habits you need, these are just quick examples. Grab film of your shot and see if you have any major shooting flaws. Then target that specific flaw in your workouts.

2. I trust that you spend time getting up reps on your own. But just shooting in an empty gym will not make you a better in game shooter. We call that blocked practice. While there’s a time and place to just get up reps, you need to add variability to your workouts. In a game you will never shoot the same shot twice. So try adding more movement, switch up your footwork, focus on how you make it, and have fun with it. You don’t need to just sit there and put up 500 shots. Design a workout where you’re focused on 100 quality reps.

3. Try your best to shoot against a defender. Most shots taken in a game are under some kind of pressure. You will often have a defender flying at you or a hand in your face. So your shooting workouts need to reflect what will happen in a game. Adding contested shooting drills to your workouts will make you more confident, it will help you shoot faster and it will improve your decision making.

4. One aspect of shooting that is often overlooked is measuring. Measure and record your makes/misses. If you shoot around 50% in an open gym, you percentage will drop significantly in a game. Aim to make around 75-80% by yourself so that in a game you’re around 40%. Every shooter needs to know their strengths and weaknesses. Measuring is important. 

+ Check the comments for a bonus tip! ☺️

Save this and drop a comment if you have any shooting questions! 

#basketballtips #basketballtraining #skilldevelopment #hoopersofinstagram #ballislife

If you are lacking confidence in your handles and find it difficult to get past defenders in games, it’s time to switch things up in your workouts.

Focusing heavily on stationary ball handling and scripted moves can only take your handles so far.

You need to develop your creativity, be able to handle pressure, improve your decision making and learn how to change speeds.

Watch any elite ball handler and they will have all of these qualities in their game.

Save these tips and work on these qualities in your next workout.

#basketballtraining #ballhandling #hoopersofinstagram #ballislife #basketballtips #hooplife #handles #basketballtrainer #basketballdrills

Are you tired of always doing boring static ball-handling warm ups? Are you looking for a new drill that is fun and challenging? It’s time to add balloon dribbling drills to your next warm up.

Here are the benefits of adding a balloon:
The balloon adds variability
The balloon makes you move and react
The balloon forces you to keep your eyes up
The balloon challenges your dribbling speed
The balloon allows for creativity
The balloon is just super fun

It doesn’t matter if you’re a beginner or advanced,  this will help you get your handles right. You can create your own constraints to make it easier or more difficult.

Save this drill and let me know in the comments if you’d like to see more fun drills like this 😊

#ballhandling #ballhandlingdrills #basketballdrills #hoopersofinstagram #nikebasketball #funworkout #basketballpractice #ballislife #basketballreels #nba #wnba

I remember the feeling of hitting big shots on this court.

But that feeling doesn’t compare to helping these young girls improve their shot.

I remember the feeling of putting on the jersey of my dream school.

But that feeling doesn’t compare to helping athletes reach their dreams.

I remember my team winning big games in this arena.

But that doesn’t compare to partnering with amazing women in this game to help grow the game.

@_r.s.j_ @rheina_ale @dez.ale @coachgnat @coachpinske 

I’m so grateful to Nike for allowing me to help run the LeBron James Chosen 1s clinic at my Alma Mater.

It was a dream come true.

📷 @creativenlb5

I’ve been a trainer for 13 years. And one of the biggest things I’ve learned is that tradition isn’t always right.

Too often as trainers and coaches we teach a skill or concept because it was how we were taught. And as a result, we end up perpetuating lies and myths.

For example, I was always told not to dip the ball when I shot. So in practice I’d force myself not to do it even though it felt more unnatural. But when I watched my game film I dipped every time. It happened naturally.

I have coaches tell many players I train to not dip arguing that it’s “slower.” Yet these same players are the best shooters on their team and never get their shot blocked, lol.

Tradition isn’t gospel. We can respect it but to grow this game we have to challenge it.

What are some other shooting myths?
Let me know in the comments!

#basketballtraining #basketballdrills #shootingdrills #ballislife #keepshooting #nikebasketball #basketballtips

If you struggle finishing with your weak hand, try this drill out in your next workout.

You can create different helpside reads by adjusting the distance of the cones or by determining who initiates the drill (offense or defense). 

Too often players just work on basic speed lay ups with no decisions to make. What I love most about this drill is watching athletes come up with their own finishing solutions. This is way more valuable than me telling them what type of finishes they should do. 

Get better today!

#basketballdrills #basketballworkout #layup #ballislife #basketballmoves #hoopersofinstagram

Basketball is like jazz.

It has a unique combination of being measured yet unpredictable.

Kyrie creatively weaving through defenders is like Coltrane playing freely and beautifully on A Love Supreme.

It’s a work of art.

But the key isn’t to dribble exactly like Kyrie.
The key is to develop your own style.

Musicians make hits using samples not covers.

Adding freestyle dribbling to your workouts will help you invent your own style. 
You’ll learn to move effortlessly.
You’ll discover the beauty of dribbling at different tempos.
You’ll quiet your mind and explore freely.
You’ll express emotions and imagine scenarios.
You’ll develop confidence and trust in yourself.
You’ll experiment and create your own moves.
You’ll enjoy the process.

Basketball is like jazz. 
Unscripted and improvisational.

Create something beautiful today.

#ballhandling #ballhandlingdrills #basketballmoves #jazz #hoopersofinstagram #ballislife #handles

Welcome to True Tuesdays!

In this series we will share truths to help you grow as a hooper, trainer and coach.

Today’s truth: 
The hustle has to match the dream. 

No matter what your dream is, hustle for it.

If your dream is to become a great shooter, does your hustle match that dream?

Are you shooting outside of scheduled practices?
Are you addressing any mechanical issues you have?
Are you putting up quality reps?
Are you adding variability to your workouts?
Are you shooting with defenders flying at you?
Are you training at the edge of your ability?

No matter the dream, you can’t dream forever.
At some point you have to wake up, hustle and work for it. 

Hustle hard today. 

#hustle #basketballadvice #chaseyourdreams #hoopersofinstagram# #freegame #ballislife #basketballtips #basketballtraining

This is one of my favorite drills to do at the end of a workout.

Drill Rules: 
•If the shot feels good leaving your hands, look away before it goes in. 
•If the shot doesn’t feel good, don’t look away at all. 

Great shooters know when a shot feels good.
So the goal of this drill is to develop the awareness of how your shot feels when the ball leaves your hands. 

As you can see, I had a lot of fun with this one.

Remember, shooting drills don’t have to be monotonous and devoid of fun for you to get better.

Steph is the greatest shooter of all-time and I’ve never witnessed a player have as much fun and play with as much joy as he does.

That is worthy of imitation.

Save this drill and try it in your next workout. 

Get better today! 

#stephcurry #shootingdrills #swish #basketballdrills #ballislife #hoopersofinstagram #threepointer #basketballtraining #basketballtrainer

It’s true what they say. 

Fear kills more dreams than failure ever will. 

It took me a long time to conqueror this fear but here are three things I learned along the way: 

1. When we acknowledge our fears, this allows us to see what’s driving it and it provides an opportunity to be vulnerable with the people we trust.

2. When we face our fears, we have the chance to find joy in taking the first step and we afford ourselves the opportunity to learn and grow. 

3. When we overcome our fears, we discover our unexplored potential and we become a better version of ourselves no matter the outcome. 

I’m grateful for the people in my life who help me push past my fears, trust myself, believe in my gifts and help me realize that everything I need is within me. 

Whatever fear is holding you back, take a step toward conquering it. Value courage over comfort. 

Share this with a friend who needs some encouragement.

Fight your fears, today.

#faceyourfears #motivation #dohardthings #nikebasketball #justdoit #basketballtrainer #basketballtips #hoopersofinstagram

Did you know that there are hundreds of different lay up variations?

A coach or trainer will never be able to teach a player every single finishing solution.

And that’s why I love the balloon.

The balloon is unpredictable so it forces athletes to find a different finishing solution on each rep. It also works on their athleticism and in-air decision making. All qualities needed to be a great finisher in games. 

In this drill, I tossed the balloon to myself and I had to hit it in the air before finishing.

But don’t get too caught up in what I’m doing. Save this video and then make it your own. Create your own drill and build it around what you or your athlete needs.

Learn from others but take ownership of your development.

Get better today.

#basketballdrills #balloon #layup #ballislife #hoopersofinstagram #basketballtrainer #basketballedits #basketballworkout

Comparison is tricky.

Sometimes it’s helpful. 
Most times it’s dangerous.

Sometimes it can inspire us to improve and change. Oftentimes, our inner critic points out everything that’s wrong with us. 

The times I had the least fun hoopin’, were the times I got caught up in the comparison game.

The year I got cut from the USA National team was the year I obsessively compared myself to Ivory Latta, the top PG in the country. 

It’s hard a lesson to learn.
But you’ll never be able to appreciate what you bring to the table if you’re always looking at someone else’s food.

Today I encourage you to: 

Count your blessings.
Focus on your craft.
Walk in your calling.
Change your self-talk. 
Create a list of your achievements.
Celebrate other people.

Save this to remind yourself that there’s no one in the world like you.

#encouragement #inspire #basketballtraining #handles #hoopersofinstagram #ballislife #begrateful #hooplife #basketballtrainer

Felt good to play again.

Drill rules:
In this drill we had another coach stand baseline and hold up 1, 2, or 3. The number indicates which type of shot you have to attempt.

1= lay up 
2= mid range pull up
3= 3 pointer

This was fun! @kdsturmy killed me with her spin move 🤦🏾‍♀️

Send this to someone you’d beat in this 1v1 drill 🤭

Get better today!

#basketballtraining #basketballworkout #ballislife #hoopersofinstagram #basketballdrills #layup #basketballtrainer

Here’s a quick ball handling warm up we did to work on footwork and changing speeds.

To be a confident ball handler in games, you have to be able to play at different paces and move well with the basketball. 

We don’t beat defenders with the ball, we beat them with our feet. 

Save this and add it to your next ball handling warm up!

 #handles #basketballskills #basketballdrills #basketballtraining #ballislife #reels #hoopersofinstagram# #ballhandlingdrills #basketballtrainer

One thing we often neglect in workouts is training the brain.

Brain fitness is just as important as physical fitness.
In games we have to remember plays, coverages, and scouting reports.

Adding drills that challenge your memory is one easy way to improve this skill.

Save this video and try this quick combo in your next workout.

Combo: (2 rounds)
BTL + Cross
BTL + BTL 
BTL + Behind the back 

BTL + Behind the back 
BTL + BTL 
BTL + Cross

Get better today.

#basketballdrills #handles #dribblingdrills #ballislife #basketballworkout #hoopersofinstagram #nikebasketball #basketballtrainer

Don’t waste your warm ups.

We love starting our sessions with a warm up that engages the body and brain in a fun and new way! 

This tennis game is a great donor sport as it trains many of the same movements and skills we need for basketball.

Starting off our sessions with competitive games like this also increases engagement and enjoyment for our players.

Fun warm ups matter so save this drill and try it to start your next workout. 

#warmup #basketballdrills #funworkout #ballislife #basketballworkout #hoopersofinstagram #nba #basketballplayer

When was the last time you just hooped alone?

No goal.
No plan.

You just went out and enjoyed yourself, by yourself, playing the game you love?

There’s value in having a plan. But there’s also immense value in hoopin’….just because.

Save this as a reminder to hoop more alone.

#hooplife #basketballtips #basketballtraining #ilovethisgame #ballislife #basketballislife #justdoitpack

As coaches and trainers we have to be okay with silence. 

Too often I see practices where coaches and trainers are constantly giving correction and feedback. 

This approach, in my opinion, robs the player of the opportunity to figure things out on their own. 

Silence is okay. You don’t have to fill the air with your voice to prove you’re good at your job. 

Player frustration is okay. Let them struggle. Let them observe. Let them figure it out. Ask more questions instead of always giving them the answer. 

No, I’m not saying never jump in. I’m saying we have to be more selective with both our praise and correction. 

The goal isn’t to have players dependent on our feedback. The goal is to teach them to be their own trainer. To make their own corrections. To help them develop the skill to know their game better than anyone else.

Players, when it comes to shooting, you should know your shot better than anyone else. Shoot more on your own to understand your authentic shot and to develop the skill to make your own adjustments.

Get in the gym and get better today.

#basketballdrills #basketballcoach #ballislife #basketballneverstops #basketballtraining #coaches

This is one of those drills that looks easy but it’s really challenging. The accountability of the tennis ball challenges you to get into low positions while maintaining your speed in transition.

Save this drill and try it out in your next workout!

#basketballdrills #handles #ballhandling #ballislife #basketballneverstops #justdoit #basketballtrainer #layup

Let’s talk about this.

Do you hate when players walk in the gym and just jack up long threes as their first shots?

Or do you see value in letting players “goof around” before their workout/practice starts?

Let me know in the comments 👇🏾

#nba #basketballgames #basketballpractice #basketballtrainer #coaches #hoopersofinstagram #hooplife #3pointer #shootyourshot

This is easily one of my favorite warm up drills.

It’s incredibly fun, it wakes up the brain, it warms up the body through variable movement and its actually harder than it looks.

Punching it correctly, most people struggle to get 10 in a row.

Save it and try to my beat my high score of 21!

#basketballdrills #basketball #ballislife #fundrills #hoopersofinstagrams #basketballdrills #basketballtrainer

Whatever it is.
Never take it for granted.

Enjoy every moment.
Cherish every experience.

Enjoy what you love today before it becomes just a memory.

#basketball #ilovethisgame #ballislife #hoopersofinstagram #inspirationalquotes #basketballtraining #basketballmotivation

One of the easiest ways for a girl to separate herself as a hooper is to develop her athleticism. 

In my experience, when I ask girls to jump over a mat or to do something in the air, they look at me crazy lol.

They doubt themselves because so many coaches and trainers doubted them and never explored these movements with them. 

But man, when it clicks…
When they get it…
When they clear that mat and score…
When they hang and manipulate the ball in the air…
The joy and elation is unmatched.
Their self confidence soars.

We have to start challenging girls to develop these traits. 

And girls.
Start believing that you’re capable of more. 

Share this with a female hooper and let’s get better today. 

#girlsbasketball #layup #wnba #girlswhohoop #basketballtraining #ballislife #basketballdrills #overtimewbb #womensbasketball

One hand control finishes are essential for your bag.

Showing the ball early baits defenders to jump before you’ve even left the ground. This buys you time to make reads and create more separation for your finish.

Here are 3 different one hand control finishes:

1. Show and switch
You use this when the defender reacts when you show the ball. When they try to block it, switch hands and finish.

2. Show and same hand finish
If the defender doesn’t react when you show the ball, simply continue on your attack line and finish with the same hand. Use your body to shield the ball.

3. Show behind the backboard
When you drive baseline you can use the backboard for added protection. Extending the ball behind the backboard keeps it further away from your defender before finishing on the opposite side. 

Save this drill and try it in your next workout.

#basketball #layup #crossover #basketballdrills #ballislife #houseofhighlights #overtimewbb #basketballtrainer #getbuckets #playmaker #girlsbasketball

Cone grabs are a great way to work on your finishes.

Finishing reads:
Cone up = Overhand lay up 
Cone down = Underhand lay up 
Cone sideways = Sidehand lay up 

Here are a few benefits of this drill:

1. Grabbing the cone provides a distraction on the drive. When driving to the rim you will encounter distractions and defenders. Being able to handle the distraction of the cone without slowing down is a major key in this drill.

2. Grabbing the cone forces you to use your off arm. This is simple yet effective accountability that will help you develop the habit of protecting the ball and creating space with your off arm. 

3. Grabbing the cone forces you to locate the cone, read the cone position and then find the rim before you shoot your lay up. You won’t always have the luxury of keeping your eyes on the rim during a drive so this is a great way to work on readjusting your eyes.

4. If you’re training by yourself you can simply toss the cone to yourself and train the same characteristics.

Save this drill and add it to your next workout.

#basketballdrills #layup #basketballworkout #ballislife #wnba #girlsbasketball #girlswhohoop #basketballtrainer #hoopersofinstagram

Coaches, let’s discuss the fade away. 
So many coaches believe this is a terrible shot but when you study the game, every elite player has this in their bag.

This is not a bad shot. This is not an off balanced shot. And the mid range is not dead.

Let’s stop limiting players and let’s give them the skills they need to be a 3 level scorer so that they’re prepared for any role on any team.

I believe every player needs a controlled fade in their game but I’d love to hear your thoughts. 

Do you think it’s a bad shot? Let’s discuss in the comments. 

#fadeaway #basketballskills #devinbooker #nba #basketballdrills #jumpshot #girlswhohoop #wnba

Your dream matters.

Too often players get stuck in the box of their current roles. 

Many end up losing their skills because they only train for the current team they’re on. Others lose their love for the game because their coach never gives them an opportunity to prove they’re capable of more.

Keep expanding your game. 
Keep learning new skills.
Keep chasing your dream. 

You can shine in your current role while working on your game to prepare for a bigger role.

You can shine in your current role and still train to become the player you always dreamed of becoming.

Train your dream.

#basketballdreams #basketballplayer #basketballskills #basketballdrills #ballislife #nba #wnba #basketballcoach #basketballtrainer #fadeaway #layup

The extended stop is a crucial 2ft finish that every player needs in their bag.

This is the most explosive 2ft finish. It allows you to take off further away from the basket and keep your momentum on the drive.

You can hit this from different angles and manipulate the ball in different ways depending on the read.

Coaches loves players who can finish off of 2ft.
Save this and work on your extended stops this week!

#basketballdrills #layup #basketballtraining #nba #basketballtrainer #demarderozan #basketballhighlights #ballislife #hoopersofinstagram

Okay, I’m not gonna lie…

This hesi was clean 🧼 lol

But there’s so much more detail here.

🏀 Skill breakdown:
Skip + drop + inside step + slide step back hesi + crossover + outside dig step + inside hand finish

Remember: If you can name the skill, you can train the skill.

And the more skilled you become at playing basketball the more creative you’ll be and the more effortlessly you’ll play.

👉Comment 🥶 if you thought this move was cold!

#shegotgame #labasketball #basketballtips #basketballmoves #basketballtrainer #shegotgame #wnba #ballislife #basketballcoach #basketballgame

Remember…

We’re not defined by how our story begins
But it takes a couple losses for us to cherish the wins

Stay grateful for your blessings
Embrace all your life lessons
When you remember your why
You’ll wonder why you still stressin’

Walk in your purpose today.

#larussell #handles #basketballmotivation #ballhandling #ballislife #basketballreels #girlsbasketball #basketballtraining #hooplife

Okay this is a good drill 😉

While working on a completely different skill (driving at a medium low height), I started to wink at the camera for fun right before I finished.

And my new favorite drill was born:
Wink Finishes 

Winking at the camera benefits: 
•Learn to adjust your eyes at the last second
•Closing one eye is an added distraction because it forces you to focus on the physical act of winking and not just looking away
• Adds variability to your finishes
•You can wink on the ground or in the air
•Filming yourself gives you immediate feedback 
•Winking made a challenging drill more fun
•Improving your wink game will just take your further in life lol

What do you guys think about this one…am I on to something or nah?

Let me know your thoughts in the comments 👇🏾

#basketballdrills #layup #basketballworkout #kyrieirving #basketballtrainer #basketballskills #girlsbasketball #hoopstudy #wnba #ballislife

Never have I ever…

Spent one hour in the gym and only worked on one drill. 😅

This drill humbled me but I learned 3 great lessons from it: 

1. Be able to pivot. Go in with a plan but don’t be married to the plan. When you discover a weakness, attack that weakness.

2. Embrace the struggle. So many players want to quit and move on when they struggle with a drill or move. But this is where true learning and growth happens.

3. Celebrate the win! Too often players get so mad that a drill took 10-20min to get down that they never celebrate the victory of finally getting it. It doesn’t matter how long something takes. When you reach the goal, celebrate the win.

Save this video for a reminder and get better today!

#basketballdrills #ballhandling #basketballworkout #ballhandlingdrills #basketballtrainer #basketballskills #girlsbasketball #hoopstudy #wnba #ballislife

Here are 3 reasons you need to try this drill today…

1. It’s a fun way to work on your handles
2. Competing against another player challenges your speed
3. You can be creative with your combos

But here’s a warning…as you can see in the video this drill can lead to laughter, frustration, debates, competitiveness and cheating, lol. I highly recommend filming it for replays. 

Lastly, just to throw this out there for grins and giggles…I’m still undefeated 😤

Share this with someone you’d beat in this drill and try it out!

#basketballdrills #ballhandling #basketballworkout #ballhandlingdrills #basketballtrainer #basketballskills #girlsbasketball #hoopstudy #wnba #ballislife
Nike, lately.

Wanna score more easily at the rim?

Learn different ways to fake a pass on your drives.

Faking a pass to the corner shooter will get help and gap defenders to jump towards the corner and open the lane for an easier finish. 

Your age, skill level or current role does not matter. Every player needs this skill in their game.

In these workouts we focused on a 2 hand fake pass into a first step finish.

Save this and add this fake and finish to your next workout.

#basketballdrills #basketballworkout #layup #basketballtrainer #basketballskills #girlsbasketball #hoopstudy #wnba #hoopersofinstagram #ballislife

Let me be honest…

In the last 6 months my training style has changed. Drastically! I was a big advocate of the Constraints Led Approach (CLA) movement. While there’s a ton of value in that style of training, I found a flaw that I just couldn’t reconcile with. 

In the CLA movement I learned to just let players do moves however they want. “Let them find their own solution” is a primary principle of that teaching style. There was freedom in letting them explore but there was no accountability and no proof of learning. 

So I had to look at some of my players’ improvement (or lack there of) and ask myself some tough questions: 
This 11 year old still can’t do a proper BTL, why is that? Do I even know how to correct what he’s doing wrong?

When you ask yourself these types of questions you’re faced with a reality that your approach may be wrong. More times than not, it’s due to a lack of knowledge of the trainer and not the player. 

It’s humbling but the growth is rewarding. 

With the college player shown above, the CLA tells me that every first step finish he does here is okay. Sure, he’s executing a first step lay up. But we can all agree that the wrong ones look weird. 

We don’t see NBA players jump like this when doing first step finishes so why would I allow him to keeping doing it that way? 

Not only that, people would look at how he’s jumping and immediately judge it because they know something looks off. 

So instead of letting him jump too far out, kick his feet up and land improperly, I corrected it. To me, he now has a real skill. A skill that can translate to the game. And maybe more importantly, it passes the eye test and looks more like Luka did in his finish. 

While I still incorporate the CLA in my workouts and find value in it, I have found that Skill Enhancement Training is a true specialty that challenges me to be insanely detailed and it gives my players more confidence because they can train this on their own and they’re able to identify when they’ve truly learned a skill. 

Keep growing. 

#basketballdrills #layup #basketballworkout #constraintsledapproach #basketballtrainer #basketballskills #possibletraining #ballislife

Teach kids Showtime!

Showtime is more than a Lakers era.
Showtime = Skills

One problem in youth basketball is that we underestimate kids. 

We don’t challenge them, we limit them.

We let them watch the pros but get mad when they imitate what they see.

We tell them that moves like a wrap pick up is too advanced and too fancy for them to learn.

But they are capable of so much more.
Especially girls! 

Don’t train kids according to their current age or current skill level.
Prepare them for their future.
Expose them to more skills.

So proud of these girls!

Let’s first address the obvious…

Pickleball got me out here lookin’ real tanned lol. But while the sun was cookin’ me, I was out there cookin’ my opponents 😂 win-win. 

Back to 🏀:
We gotta get away from the obsession that everything needs to be game like. For the longest time I thought stationary ball handling had no value because of that.

But drills don’t have to be a direct reflection of the game to have value.

Practicing wide open shots is not game like
Small sided games with an advantage start is not game like
Tossing and catching a cone is not game like
Audio cues are not game like
Dribbling 2 balls is not game like

But they all have value.

The key is to know what skills you’re targeting and what weaknesses you’re trying to address.

Don’t do drills just for the sake of it.

Resolve to challenge yourself, target your weaknesses, add accountability and work on your game with purpose.

Save this fun yet very difficult stationary ball handling drill and try it in your next workout.

This post is solely for educational purposes…

The mark of a great shooter/scorer is in one’s ability to hit consecutive shots in a different way each time. 

In a game no 2 shots are the same.

Every point I scored was different.
Every basket @stephencurry30 made was different. 

Different spots. 
Different distances. 
Different footwork. 
Different reads. 
Same result! 

So if you aren’t fixing something in your form, your training should include a lot of variability.

Shooting in one spot for high reps has its place but many players struggle to be great in-game shooters because they never practice variability.

Making 5-10 different types of shots in a row has more bang for the buck than making 10 in a row from one spot.

Variability is king.
And on that day, I was queen of the court. 😉

To dip or not to dip…

As a player I was always taught not to “bring the ball down”. But when I studied my USC game film I consistently dipped the ball off the catch. 

I naturally did the opposite of what I was taught.

As a trainer I can’t tell you how many times I’ve had players (often the best shooters on their team) tell me that their coach forces them not to dip the ball because it’s too slow.

But is it really?

Telling a player not to dip the ball off the catch is like telling a quarterback not to take his arm back before throwing a football because it’s too slow.

You restrict natural movements.

Dipping the ball creates flow, energy and power.

And the fact that PG said Klay was the first person he saw intentionally shoot without a dip proves how common dipping is. 

So I am pro dip off the catch.

But I also recognize that there will be times when players need alternative solutions. 

The game is full of too many variables to tell a player that they should always dip the ball.

Ex: If I receive a pass at my hip level, there is no need to dip. 

If the shot clock is running down and I receive a high pass, I may not have time to dip.

So I believe you should also practice for situations where time and space are limited. There will be times when no dip is the best solution.

Klay naturally shoots with a dip.
But he also trains the unnatural.

Be adaptable.

If you can learn to shoot from different starting points you have the potential to become a cheat code.
Like Klay.

Do you use the dip? Do you teach it? 
Let me know in the comments ⬇️

#shootingdrills #splashbros #thewarriors #basketballtrainer #basketballskills #podcast #basketballworkout #klaythompson #labasketball #ballislife #basketballdrills

Now let me start off by saying…

I used to teach players to shoot with their guide hand low on the side of the ball.

I taught what I was taught.
I taught what I thought I did as a shooter.
I taught what most other shooting coaches taught.

But then I looked for evidence to support my stance.

I came up empty.

I couldn’t find great shooters who shot with their guide hand low on the side of the ball.

But there was evidence of elite shooters with their fingers on top of the ball. And I’m talking elite shooters at every level. 

It was overwhelming and hard to ignore.

So I made the change to my own shot first.

It was an easy adjustment, it felt more comfortable, the ball was more secure in my hands and my range increased. 

More importantly, many of my players have become better shooters because of it. 

Most common guide hand problems were fixed by just moving the fingers to the top of the ball. 

We all have shooting philosophies.

But I challenge you to start asking yourself:

Does my shooting philosophy align with what great shooters actually do? 

Because real evidence > traditional teaching

What are your thoughts on the guide hand placement?
Let me know in the comments!

The midrange isn’t dead.

If you struggle with getting your midrange off, here are 4 qualities you should work on:

1. Low shoulders
When your shoulders are low your defender will be inclined to defend your drive. When they anticipate the drive you can create space by stopping on a dime to elevate for the jumper. Your body position is everything. 

2. Outside pick up
This is all about protection. If you’re driving right and your defender is on your left hip, pick up the ball near the outside of your right hip. Having the ability to shoot from a different lift path is a major key to keep the ball protected and to get the shot off faster. 

3. Feet unsquared 
When you shoot off the dribble you don’t always have to square your feet on the ground. Keeping your feet unsquared on the ground keeps the ball protected and it allows you to get your shot off quicker.

4. Square in the air
This is connected to point #3. When you square up in the air you’re aligning the shoulder toward the rim. In addition, this will create more separation between you and your defender as your outside leg naturally rotates toward the rim. 

*BONUS* 

5. Higher lift point
Players who have a great midrange game have the ability to adjust their lift points higher to shoot over taller defenders. The form you use to shoot a wide open 3 will often differ from the form you need to shoot a contested pull up.

Save these tips and work on that midrange this week.

Stop trying to always beat your defender.

Scoring isn’t only about getting past someone.
It’s also about your understanding of space.

When you have space, do you know how to keep it?
Can you create more of it?

One of the best ways to keep your space is to use partial steps. This puts your defender on their heels and it gives you time to make reads.

The use of extended steps can help you create even more space after your partial steps.

In the clip above, I created more space by using an extended step to get into my speed stop.

Jordan Poole aggressively hits an extended step at Luka on his thru to create more space for his jumper. 

Knowing how to flow between partial steps and extended steps will take your game to the next level.

Save this video and get better today.

Let’s play truth or dare 

Truth: 
Your back does not need to be straight (chest up) when you prepare to shoot the basketball.

It is both unnatural and uncomfortable.
When squatting in general our backs are never completely straight. 

So when you prepare to shoot, slightly lean the shoulders forward.

You will not get in your own way (when you curve the ball during your lift path). 

You will not create negative energy (the back naturally straightens when you jump).

In fact, when your shoulders are slightly forward, it will feel more effortless because you’ll have less tension in your body and you will be able to create more power and energy (study Olympic lifters).

Dare: 
I dare you to challenge traditional teaching. 

When coaches try to prove their methods by only showing you their shot or their players’ shot it’s simply circular reasoning. 

I dare you to demand real evidence. Respectfully. 

I dare you to study what the best shooters in the world do and try this out for yourself.

Share this post and get better today.

Hitting a baseline euro takes skill.

Having the ability to do a euro step on one side of the basket and then finish on the opposite side isn’t easy.

An inside hand finish requires you to hang in the air, extend towards the rim and add some wrist spin. 

The outside hand finish Kyrie hit is even tougher because you have to hang and square the body in the air. 

Do you have this euro in your 🎒?

As a kid I was incredibly shy.

Ask me to speak in front of a group, on the court or in the classroom and I would freak out.

To the point of tears.

As a point guard, my shyness didn’t go over too well with coaches. They concluded I was “too cool for school” and would just yell at me for not leading vocally.

But I wasn’t too cool.
I was never taught how to lead or told what to say. 

I was given an expectation without any education or preparation.

I wasn’t too cool.
I was just a shy player who also suffered silently from social anxiety.

So when I watch videos of myself on the court confidently speaking and courageously teaching the game I love, I can’t help but be filled with immense gratitude.

I can’t help but thank God for how far He’s brought me.

I can’t help but be grateful for the players, parents, coaches and businesses that trust me as a leader.

I can’t help but be proud of myself for learning how to win the inner game.

I can’t help but be grateful for those who taught me how to lead, championed my gifts and helped me find my voice.

Thank you!

I’m forever ever grateful ✨

Let’s jump into this shooting film study. 

While everyone’s shot may have subtle differences, there are a few techniques that every great shooter abides by that leads to shooting consistently, effortlessly and fluidly.

Here are the 3 main differences I see in LeBron’s shot vs Steph’s in these clips: 

1. Lift Path
When LeBron lifts the ball from his start position, the ball moves to the left before getting to his set point. In short, it changes directions. Steph’s lift path stays on the same line. Less variability leads to more consistency.

2. Hip Engagement
LeBron only uses his upper body. To me this makes his shot look a little stiff and it can lead to a throwing motion vs a pushing motion. Steph’s hips are loaded before he releases the ball. Loading your hips creates energy and power.

3. Hand Placement
Watch this video a few times. You’ll notice that LeBron’s off hand is low, more towards the front of the ball and the palm is off the ball. Conversely, Steph’s off hand fingers are toward the top and his whole hand rests on the ball. Having your off hand toward the top of the ball will give you more control and stability (no matter your hand size).

This breakdown is no knock on LeBron. He’s a 🐐for a reason and his shot works for him.

But we can’t deny that Steph is greatest shooter of all time.

Study what the best do to become one of the best.

Did I miss anything?
Do you notice any other differences in their shot?

Let me know in the comments!

Oh, and get those reps up today!

#shootingdrills #stephcurry #lebronjames #basketballtrainer #basketballskills #swish #basketballworkout #basketballtips #formshooting #ballislife #basketballdrills

The great debate: 1 motion vs 2 motion

Contrary to popular belief, you need both in your game. 

But I get why seeing players shoot with two different forms may be perplexing for JJ. 

He grew up in the 2 motion shot era. What he’s seeing today goes against what he was taught.

But here’s why you need a one motion shot and a two motion shot:

It gives you options. 

Open for a wide open 3? 
You don’t need to jump high with a release high. Shoot an easier one motion shot. 

Shooting a contested pull up? 
Shooting at the top of your jump allows you to shoot over the defense. Shoot a two motion shot. 

Tempted to shoot it from the logo?
Better make it one motion. A quick study of Steph, Dame, Caitlyn and Trae will prove that low lift points make it easier to shoot it from deep. 

Remember, adaptability is king!

If you only have one shooting form, your shot options are limited and you’re easier to defend.

You don’t have to forsake one for the other.

Dame proves that you can have endless range with a one motion shot and you can hit highly contested shots with a two motion shot.

You just gotta work for it.

What are your thoughts on one motion vs two motion shots? 

Let me know in the comments!

Here’s what I’d do differently if I played again at USC:

1. Spend more time alone in the gym 🏀
I worked out during the off-season but I didn’t keep that up once team practices started. Schedules can be crazy but I would find at least 10-20 minutes to work on just one skill a few times per week.

2. Spend more time studying film 🎥
I don’t know how I expected to separate myself and gain the trust of my coaches & teammates when I only watched film when it was required. I’d be a true student of the game. 

3. Train my mind 🧘🏾‍♀️
I struggled with shyness and I had a fixed mindset. If I played today, I’d tap into mental health resources. I’d seek out our sports psychologist for guidance and accountability. I’d also develop a pre-practice and pre-game routine to help me win the inner game.

4. Pay attention to my diet 🥗
I ate so poorly. I thought working out cancelled bad eating habits. If I played again, I’d hire a personal chef from my NIL money lol 

5. Choose a better major 📚
I was a good student at USC (3.5gpa). But ball was life for me. I didn’t have a plan outside of hoopin’ so I just picked a major many athletes chose: Sociology. If I could do it over, I would explore my interests and skillsets to create a plan for life after basketball.

6. Pick a hobby 📸
Being a student-athlete is hard. Finding time to do something that you love outside of your sport is so important for your mental health and happiness. For me, I’d picked up my film camera and explore street photography

Remember to invest in your dream.
Remember that the grind shouldn’t stop after you earn a scholarship.
Remember to tap into your resources.
Remember that mental health matters.
Remember that you’re more than an athlete.
Remember to make every moment count…on and off the court. 

Save this video if one of these tips resonated with you.

3️⃣ reasons you should do this drill 👇

1. It’s fun
Having fun in training is so underrated. Starting a practice or workout with smiles, laughter and high energy keeps engagement up and sets the tone for the rest of the workout. Fun matters. 

2. There’s variability
Every read is different. Every lay up is different. Adding drills with variability will help you become a better finisher in games and it will help you tap into your creativity.

3. Improves Awareness
Getting your shot blocked from behind sucks. I’m sure that finals block LeBron got on Iguodola haunts him. Chase down blocks happen all the time. This drill teaches you how to peek over your shoulder, change speeds and use fakes to avoid the block.

👉Save this reel and try this drill in your next team practice or training session

I’m telling y’all…
If you want to improve your shooting learn how to find the seams.

Whether off of a bad pass or off the dribble, the best shooters have developed the habit of finding the seams.

This hand readjustment drill is a great way to develop this skill.

Readjusting the ball and finding the seams helps you get that perfect hold and ideal hand placement. And if you’ve got good hands, it’ll lead to beautiful rotation on the ball.

Readjusting your hands does not slow your down your shot.

The 🔑 is to make sure your hands are set before you get your feet are set. If you do that, you’ll keep the same natural flow to your shot.

What I love about this drill is that you can do it alone, without a basket or with someone closing out on you.

One Day

One day I dreamt of winning a championship.
Then one day it happened and we won the National Championship at Narbonne High. 

One day I dreamt of earning a scholarship to my dream school.
Then one day I woke up and put on a USC jersey with number 1 on the back. 

One day I dreamt of hearing my name called on Draft Day.
Then one day in April of 2009, I got that call and was the 23rd overall pick.

One day I sat in my business class dreaming of starting a Basketball Sports Academy.
Then one day, over 10 years ago, True Point Guard was born.

One day I dreamt of working with Nike.
Then one day I drove downtown and saw myself on a billboard in a Nike ad. 

Today may be one of those days you’re still dreaming.

May this encourage you to keep chasing that day. 

That day when you’ll look in the mirror and say, “I did it!”

That day when you’ll look behind you and thank everyone who supported and sacrificed for you.

That day when you’ll look at what you’ve accomplished with humility and gratitude.

That day when you’ll use your story to encourage and inspire the world.

Chase that day.

Here are the top 3 mistakes I made when I first became a trainer:

1️⃣ I didn’t have my own style 
When I first started I either did drills that my coaches did with me as a player or I copied what popular trainers did at the time. It’s not bad to use drills you see other people doing but know WHY you’re doing it and add your own flavor to it. 

2️⃣ I thought training pros equated to true success
Training pros is not the bar. Training pros does not mean you’re a great trainer. Early on, I chased a dream that didn’t fit my passion. I love working with the youth and impacting the game at that level. Starting with a player in middle school and watching them play for their varsity team or earn a scholarship is the goal for me. Define your own meaning of success.

3️⃣ I didn’t study the game, I studied drills 
When I first started out I was not a student of the game. I was a student of drills. There’s a BIG difference. When you study the game for yourself, you you develop an eye for detail. When you study the game for yourself, you’re able to identify trends and skills to teach your players. When you study film for yourself, your knowledge and confidence will grow. If you want to separate yourself, do your own research so that you can create drills that solve problems for your players. 

BONUS: 
I didn’t have a community
Being a trainer can be a lonely road but it doesn’t have to be. When I first started I just did my own thing in my corner of the basketball world. But we are all made for community. If you want to thrive, be challenged and serve others, find a community of trainers and coaches. For the game to grow, we have to grow together. Find your tribe.

If you can relate comment below.
Let’s keep growing!

I wish I had this skill when I played 🤦🏾‍♀️

Having a turn push in your game is crucial.

When splitting traps and driving past a gap defender, having the ability to push the ball into open space and regain control is a necessary skill that can prevent turnovers and lead to easy scoring opportunities.

So many players don’t know how to let go of the ball while remaining in control of the ball.

So how can you train and prepare for these moments when training by yourself?

An accountability tool.

Using an accountability tool helps you work on the precision of the dribble and it forces you to lock in on the details and the technique.

Learn how to train and prepare for these moments with or without defenders. 

Save this skill stack and work on your turn push in your next workout!

Shout out to @franknittyy! We loved working on his skill stack. He’s one of the smoothest and most skilled players I’ve ever watched play. LA hoopers are just different 😉

Get better today.

Tap here ✋

Here are 3 ways to quickly bounce back from a bad game:

1. FIND THE GOOD 
We have a tendency to highlight our negatives. But no matter how badly you think you played, there will always be things that you did well. Find the good! After your games list 3-5 things you did well. It doesn’t matter if it’s big or small just be specific and make this a post-game habit. 

2. STUDY YOUR FILM 
Watch your film to see where you struggled. Don’t run to film when you play well and shy away from it when you play terribly. Sit down with your coach and learn from your mistakes. Then get in the gym and work on those things. In my clips above I shot like 2/12 that day 😭 When I studied my film I noticed that my shot selection was terrible. Trying to shoot over @jjchaikovsky is like trying to shoot over Wemby. So I know I need to work on creating more separation and using more fakes. Lesson learned. 

3. HIT THE RESET BUTTON 
One bad game doesn’t mean you’ll play poorly in your next game. And dwelling on it too long won’t change the past. Take ownership and then hit the reset button! You are not defined by one bad game. Learn from it and then prepare for the next game. Here is a great reset phrase to say to yourself: Let’s get the next one!

Bad games can be frustrating and embarrassing. But they can be truly valuable if you view them as an opportunity to learn and grow.

The bounce back isn’t easy but it’s possible!

Share this with an athlete or your team today. Encourage them to keep going and keep growing.

Contrary to popular belief…

Making changes to your shot doesn’t have to take months or years.

Tweaks can be made in a few minutes, hours or days.

Shooting isn’t as complicated as we make it seem.

You just have to understand the basic anatomy of shooting, be willing to let go of what you’re comfortable with and put up the reps.

@jiangdaniel8539 has been working on his shot for just over a week and the changes have been incredible.

His old form in the mid range didn’t look terrible. But there were certain qualities he was missing for his mid range to actually work in a game. 

Once we made those tweaks, his shot now passes the eye test (it looks better), it’s more fluid and he’s got a mid range jumper that allows him to elevate and shoot over defenders. 

Can you spot the differences in these clips?

This has always been an interesting debate…

Should your eyes follow the ball on your release or stare at the rim?

I see great shooters do both.

I personally don’t look at the ball when I shoot. I’ve tried it and it just feels weird.

But I do believe it has benefits in training to check your rotation. Your eyes can be accountability. 

But I don’t teach one or the other. I let players do what feels comfortable and natural for them.

What about you…
What do your eyes do when you shoot?
What do you teach your players to do?

Let’s talk about it in the comments👇

“Work on your weaknesses.”

As coaches and trainers we tell our players to do this all the time. 

But we have to start taking our own advice.

When was the last time you designed a workout to work on one of your weaknesses?

When was the last time you taught a new skill or concept?

When was the last time you watched film just to breakdown your teaching and communication style? 

Keep helping your players get better. 
But don’t forget that every time you step on the floor it’s an opportunity for you to work on your skills too. 

Be intentional.
Get uncomfortable. 
Keep growing.

Man, I tell you the truth…

If I knew about these 2 hesi moves when I played, I would’ve averaged 4-6 more ppg. I would’ve spammed that hip swivel 😂

But when I was growing up any type of freeze move or change of pace move was called a hesi.

If you asked 10 different people to show you a hesi, they’d show you 10 different moves. 

But hesi is a movement category.
There are so many types! 

This is why naming moves is important.

If you can name it, you can train it.
And if you can train it, you can intentionally add it to the bag.

What’s your favorite hesi move?
Let me know in the comments!

Shooting slumps happen. 

Slumps are no respecter of persons.
They’re inevitable.

So I’ve got 3 ways to help you quickly get out of a shooting slump: 

1️⃣ Add variability to your shooting drills
Break up your routine. Standing in one place and shooting high reps has its place and it can help build your confidence. But this is common and what most players do all the time. More of the same may not help you get out of that slump.

The game is random. No two shots are ever the same. 

To get out of a slump, try and add more variability to your shooting drills. Shoot with different footworks, shoot off of bad passes or try shooting from different distances on each shot. 

Adding variability will help you get out of a slump faster.

2️⃣ Do more contested shooting drills
Wide open shots are rare. Your training should often reflect what you’ll see in a game. Most shots in game are taken under the pressure of someone closing out on you or you’ll shoot with a hand in your face. 

If you find yourself in a shooting slump, try some contested shooting drills to build your confidence back up (check my stories for drill ideas). 

3️⃣ Find the good 
When we’re in slumps we dwell on the negative. We focus on everything that’s going wrong. Staying in that state of mind will only prolong your slump. So find the good. Highlight 3-5 things you do well in each game. Shifting to positive thoughts will help your game and help you believe in your shot.

In addition, don’t let your slump negatively impact who you are as a teammate. Find the good and find other ways to contribute and cheer for your teammates. 

Remember, confidence is a skill that’s practiced. If you’re not putting up reps and working hard on your own, you’re probably not in a slump. You’re likely just not a great shooter yet.

Only shooters get in slumps. 

But you have the power to change that. 

👉Save this post for later and get better today.

You need this finish in your bag 🎒

The swing step with a 1 hand tuck is a killer combo to protect the ball and create separation on a drive.

The swing step can look easy but it can be tricky. 

A lot of players end up doing euro steps so the details are key. 

When you train your swing step, the key is to make sure that the outside foot swings across your body along with your hips and shoulders turning in the same direction.

You can add different types of pick ups but a 1 hand tuck allows you to use your body for extra protection while keeping your momentum on the swing step.

Save this video and spend 20 minutes improving your swing step in your next workout.
